message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Xatkit: A Multimodal Low-Code Chatbot Development Framework
Paper Abstract: Chatbot (and voicebot) applications are increasingly adopted in various domains such as e-commerce or customer services as a direct communication channel between companies and end-users. Multiple frameworks have been developed to ease their definition and deployment. While these frameworks are efficient to design simple chatbot applications, they still require advanced technical knowledge to define complex interactions and are difficult to evolve along with the company needs (e.g. it is typically impossible to change the NL engine provider). In addition, the deployment of a chatbot application usually requires a deep understanding of the targeted platforms, especially back-end connections, increasing the development and maintenance costs. In this paper, we introduce the Xatkit framework. Xatkit tackles these issues by providing a set of Domain Specific Languages to define chatbots (and voicebots and bots in general) in a platform-independent way. Xatkit also comes with a runtime engine that automatically deploys the chatbot application and manages the defined conversation logic over the platforms of choice. Xatkit's modular architecture facilitates the separate evolution of any of its components. Xatkit is open source and fully available online.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what you should know about natural language processing:

## Definition and Overview

Natural language processing (NLP) is the processing of natural language information by a computer. NLP is a subfield of computer science and is closely associated with artificial intelligence.(no content)NLP is also related to information retrieval, knowledge representation, computational linguistics, and linguistics more broadly.

## Main Tasks

Major processing tasks in an NLP system include: speech recognition, text classification, natural language understanding, and natural language generation.

## Historical Development

Natural language processing has its roots in the 1950s.(no content)Up until the 1980s, most natural language processing systems were based on complex sets of hand-written rules. Starting in the late 1980s, however, there was a revolution in natural language processing with the introduction of machine learning algorithms for language processing.

## Recent Advances

The Transformer architecture was introduced in 2017.(no content)The concept of large language model (LLM) emerged in late 2010s. LLM is a language model trained with self-supervised learning on vast amount of text.(no content)In recent years, advancements in deep learning and large language models have significantly enhanced the capabilities of natural language processing, leading to widespread applications in areas such as healthcare, customer service, and content generation.

Web search results for query: "Software deployment"

Links: [{"title":"Software deployment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_deployment"},{"title":"Deployment environment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deployment_environment"},{"title":"Deployment management - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deployment_management"},{"title":"Continuous deployment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_deployment"},{"title":"HP Client Automation Software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HP_Client_Automation_Software"},{"title":"Application-release automation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application-release_automation"},{"title":"EMCO Remote Installer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EMCO_Remote_Installer"},{"title":"Hybrid SaaS - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hybrid_SaaS"},{"title":"Brownfield (software development) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brownfield_(software_development)"},{"title":"Capistrano (software) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capistrano_(software)"}]

I've completed the web search for "Software deployment". Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Software deployment is all of the activities that make a software system available for use.(no content)Deployment can involve activities on the producer (software developer) side or on the consumer (user) side or both.

## Key Concepts

**Deployment Environments**: Deployment architectures broadly range from development (DEV) to production (PROD), with a common 4-tier architecture including development, testing, model, and production (DEV, TEST, MODL, PROD).

**Modern Approaches**: Continuous deployment (CD) is a software engineering approach in which software functionalities are delivered frequently and through automated deployments.(no content)Continuous deployment has been adopted by software companies such as Meta, Microsoft, Atlassian, IBM, Adobe, and Tesla.

**Release Strategies**: When deploying a new release to production, rather than immediately deploying to all instances or users, it may be deployed to a single instance or fraction of users first, and then either deployed to all or gradually deployed in phases, in order to catch any last-minute problems, referred to as a canary release.

**Release Automation**: Application-release automation (ARA) refers to the process of packaging and deploying an application or update of an application from development, across various environments, and ultimately to production.

The search results provide comprehensive information about software deployment practices, tools, and methodologies used in modern software development.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Chatbot"

Links: [{"title":"Chatbot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chatbot"},{"title":"Category:Chatbots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Chatbots"},{"title":"Gemini (chatbot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gemini_(chatbot)"},{"title":"Grok (chatbot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grok_(chatbot)"},{"title":"List of chatbots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_chatbots"},{"title":"DeepSeek (chatbot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeepSeek_(chatbot)"},{"title":"Tay (chatbot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tay_(chatbot)"},{"title":"Kimi (chatbot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kimi_(chatbot)"},{"title":"Alice AI (AI model family) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alice_AI_(AI_model_family)"}]

Here are the search results for "Chatbot":

## Definition

A chatbot (originally chatterbot) is a software application or web interface designed to have textual or spoken conversations.(no content)Modern chatbots are typically online and use generative artificial intelligence systems that are capable of maintaining a conversation with a user in natural language and simulating the way a human would behave as a conversational partner.

## Technology

Simpler chatbots have existed for decades, while more advanced ones often use deep learning and natural language processing.(no content)Modern chatbots like ChatGPT are often based on large language models called generative pre-trained transformers (GPT), which are based on a deep learning architecture called the transformer containing artificial neural networks, and generate text after being trained on a large text corpus.

## Applications

A major area where chatbots have long been used is customer service and support, with various sorts of virtual assistants.(no content)Many banks, insurers, media companies, e-commerce companies, airlines, hotel chains, retailers, health care providers, government entities, and restaurant chains have used chatbots to answer simple questions, increase customer engagement, for promotion, and to offer additional ways to order from them.

## Recent Growth

Chatbots have increased in popularity as part of the AI boom of the 2020s, and the popularity of ChatGPT, followed by competitors such as Gemini, Claude and later Grok.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Domain-specific language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain-specific_language"},{"title":"Domain-specific modeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain-specific_modeling"},{"title":"Talk:Domain-specific language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Domain-specific_language"},{"title":"Category:Domain-specific programming languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Domain-specific_programming_languages"},{"title":"Domain-specific multimodeling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domain-specific_multimodeling"},{"title":"Semantic domain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_domain"},{"title":"Planning Domain Definition Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planning_Domain_Definition_Language"},{"title":"SAS language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAS_language"},{"title":"General-purpose language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General-purpose_language"},{"title":"Automatic taxonomy construction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_taxonomy_construction"}]

## Domain-Specific Language (DSL)

A domain-specific language (DSL) is a computer language specialized to a particular application domain.(no content)This is in contrast to a general-purpose language (GPL), which is broadly applicable across domains.

### Key Characteristics

There are a wide variety of DSLs, ranging from widely used languages for common domains, such as HTML for web pages, down to languages used by only one or a few pieces of software.(no content)DSLs can be further subdivided by the kind of language, and include domain-specific markup languages, domain-specific modeling languages, and domain-specific programming languages.

### Benefits and Applications

Creating a domain-specific language can be worthwhile if the language allows a particular type of problem or solution to be expressed more clearly than an existing language would allow and the type of problem in question reappears sufficiently often.(no content)Domain-specific modeling languages tend to support higher-level abstractions than general-purpose modeling languages, so they require less effort and fewer low-level details to specify a given system. Additionally, domain-specific modeling often includes the idea of code generation: automating the creation of executable source code directly from the domain-specific language models, which can significantly improve developer productivity.

### Examples

The command line utility grep has a regular expression syntax which matches patterns in lines of text, and the sed utility defines a syntax for matching and replacing regular expressions.

Web search results for query: "Voice interface"

Links: [{"title":"Voice interface card - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voice_interface_card"},{"title":"Voice user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voice_user_interface"},{"title":"Conversational user interface - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conversational_user_interfaces"},{"title":"Visual Interactive Voice Response - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_Interactive_Voice_Response"},{"title":"Google Home (platform) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_Home_(platform)"},{"title":"Dvorak on Typing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dvorak_on_Typing"},{"title":"Android TV - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google_TV_(interface)"},{"title":"The New Voice of Ukraine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_Voice_of_Ukraine"},{"title":"Speech recognition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speech_recognition"},{"title":"Radio Network Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_Network_Controller"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about voice interfaces:

## Voice User Interfaces (VUI)

A voice-user interface (VUI) enables spoken human interaction with computers, using speech recognition to understand spoken commands and answer questions, and typically text to speech to play a reply.

## Key Capabilities

Newer voice command devices are speaker-independent, so they can respond to multiple voices, regardless of accent or dialectal influences, and are capable of responding to several commands at once, separating vocal messages, and providing appropriate feedback, accurately imitating a natural conversation.

## Technology Behind Voice Interfaces

Advances in technologies like text-to-speech, speech-to-text, natural language processing, and cloud services contributed to the mass adoption of these types of interfaces.

## Common Applications

Speech recognition applications include voice user interfaces where the user speaks to a device, which "listens" and processes the audio, with common voice applications including interpreting commands for calling, call routing, home automation, and aircraft control.

## Benefits and Challenges

VUIs have become more commonplace, and people are taking advantage of the value that these hands-free, eyes-free interfaces provide in many situations. However, voice user interfaces tend to suffer from low discoverability: it is difficult for users to understand the scope of a system's capabilities.

Popular examples of voice interfaces include Amazon Echo, Apple's Voice Control on iOS devices, and Google Assistant.

Links: [{"title":"E-commerce - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-commerce"},{"title":"Types of e-commerce - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Types_of_e-commerce"},{"title":"E-commerce in India - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-commerce_in_India"},{"title":"E-commerce in Bangladesh - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-commerce_in_Bangladesh"},{"title":"Brushing (e-commerce) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brushing_(e-commerce)"},{"title":"E-commerce payment system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-commerce_payment_system"},{"title":"European e-commerce VAT directive - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_e-commerce_VAT_directive"},{"title":"Livestreaming e-commerce in China - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Livestreaming_e-commerce_in_China"},{"title":"E-commerce in Southeast Asia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E-commerce_in_Southeast_Asia"},{"title":"Comparison of shopping cart software - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_free_software_e-commerce_web_application_frameworks"}]

I've performed a web search for "E-commerce" and found comprehensive information about the topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

E-commerce (electronic commerce) refers to commercial activities including the electronic buying or selling products and services which are conducted on online platforms or over the Internet.(no content)E-commerce typically uses the web for at least a part of a transaction's life cycle although it may also use other technologies such as e-mail.

## Main Types

There are three areas of e-commerce: online retailing, electronic markets, and online auctions. Additionally, Business-to-consumer (B2C), or direct-to-consumer, is the most common e-commerce model. It deals in electronic business relationships between businesses—both producers and service providers—with end consumers.

## Technologies and Methods

E-commerce draws on technologies such as mobile commerce, electronic funds transfer, supply chain management, Internet marketing, online transaction processing, electronic data interchange (EDI), inventory management systems, and automated data collection systems.(no content)E-commerce businesses may also employ some or all of the following: Online shopping for retail sales direct to consumers via web sites and mobile apps, conversational commerce via live chat, chatbots, and voice assistants.

## Benefits

The existence value of e-commerce is to allow consumers to shop online and pay online through the Internet, saving the time and space of customers and enterprises, greatly improving transaction efficiency, especially for busy office workers, and also saving a lot of valuable time.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

It deals in electronic business relationships between businesses—both producers and service providers—with end consumers.

## Technologies and Methods

E-commerce draws on technologies such as mobile commerce, electronic funds transfer, supply chain management, Internet marketing, online transaction processing, electronic data interchange (EDI), inventory management systems, and automated data collection systems.(no content)E-commerce businesses may also employ some or all of the following: Online shopping for retail sales direct to consumers via web sites and mobile apps, conversational commerce via live chat, chatbots, and voice assistants.

## Benefits

The existence value of e-commerce is to allow consumers to shop online and pay online through the Internet, saving the time and space of customers and enterprises, greatly improving transaction efficiency, especially for busy office workers, and also saving a lot of valuable time.

## Low-Code Development Overview

Based on the search results, here's what you should know about low-code development:

### Definition and Basics

A low-code development platform (LCDP) provides a software development environment – typically a graphical user interface (GUI) – that involves little or no writing of code.(no content)LCDPs are based on the principles of model-driven architecture, automatic code generation, and visual programming.

### Key Features and Benefits

Because they require less coding knowledge, nearly anyone in a software development environment can learn to use a low-code development platform.(no content)Features like drag and drop interfaces help users visualize and build the application.(no content)Mobile accessibility is one of the driving factors of using low-code development platforms. Instead of developers having to spend time creating multi-device software, low-code packages typically come with that feature as standard.

### Market and Historical Context

The low-code development platform market traces its origins back to 2011. The specific name "low-code" was not put forward until 9 June, 2014, when it was used by the industry analyst Forrester Research.

### Notable Platforms

Some widely-used low-code platforms include Mendix, which provides tools for organizations to build web and mobile applications using visual drag-and-drop elements, OutSystems, a low-code platform for omnichannel enterprise application development, and Salesforce, a low-code platform for enterprise application development, especially CRM and ERP.

### Concerns and Challenges

Concerns over low-code development platform security and compliance are growing, especially for apps that use consumer data. There can be concerns over the security of apps built so quickly and possible lack of due governance leading to compliance issues.

6. **E-commerce** - Used task as a key application domain
7. **Low-code development platform** - Proposed concept that describes Xatkit's approach

All entities include:

- Clear relevance statements
